spans.content: Removal of ammonia nitrogen and phosphorus by porous slow-release
ceramsite prepared from industrial solid wastes
Changjin Ou a, Junyue Wang a, Wenxuan Yang a, Yuqing Bao a, Zhipeng Liao a, Jian Shi b, Juan Qin a,*
a Nantong Key Laboratory of Intelligent and New Energy Materials, School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nantong University, Nantong 226019, China
<sup>b</sup> Analysis and Testing Center, Nantong University, Nantong 226019, China
An environmentally friendly ceramsite with slow-release ability was prepared using industrial solid wastes through sintering method.

release was mainly evoked by wollastonite, and the porous structure ensured the release process slow but persistent. P removal efficiency of the ceramsite was verified by static and dynamic adsorption, respectively. By regulating pH to a highly alkaline condition independently and releasing sufficient
, P was efficiently removed by forming hydroxyapatite, with an equilibrium adsorption capacity of 0.2425 mg/g and removal efficiency of
. Meanwhile, the ceramsite was applied to a BAF to investigate the feasibility of the simultaneous removal of
-N and P. Results indicated their average removal efficiencies could be stabilized above
over a long-term operation. The high-efficiency
-N removal was ensured by the nitrification and the intensification of diatoms photosynthesis, while P removal was a result of chemical and physical adsorption.

Nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P), as the two most fundamental elements of all organisms, play a crucial role in the synthesis of DNA, RNA and the transfer of energy [1]. However, with the growth of the world population and the intensification of industrialization, excessive N and P are discharged and cause numerous environmental problems, including oxygen depletion and eutrophication, severely affecting ecology balance and even public health [2,3]. Conventional technologies tend to focus on the removal of one nutrient [4]. However, P frequently coexists with N in many types of wastewater. According to the wastewater quality standards for discharge to municipal sewers (CJ 343-2010), the maximum permissible concentrations of the total N (TN), ammonia N
, respectively. Consequently, simultaneous removal of N and P (SPN) is essential for wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) to promote the development of a sustainable society.
process is the most traditional process for SPN in WWTPs, which is a single activated sludge system [5]. However, the
process faces two major limits. Firstly, the sludge retention time (SRT) of phosphorus accumulating organisms (PAOs) is

significantly shorter than that of nitrifiers, so nitrifiers are easy to lose during the sludge discharge process. Secondly, denitrifiers compete with PAOs for carbon sources in the anaerobic zone, and P release process of PAOs is commonly inhibited and occurs after the denitrification is completed [6]. These can result in the excessive existence of
-N and P in the secondary effluent, so starting upgrade and reconstruction projects for WWTPs is imperative [7].

Biological aerated filter (BAF) is a widely acclaimed fixed-film biosystem for wastewater treatment now, which can realize the simultaneous removal of several organic pollutants and greatly reduce the amount of activated sludge [8]. Particularly, BAFs have been demonstrated to be an effective strategy to remove

-N at a high level since they can achieve the nitrification at small footprint [9]. However, previous studies about BAFs are scarcely specialized in P removal. When low P concentration is desired in the final effluent, chemical dosing, e.g., alum, is chosen to assist with BAFs, which increases not only the cost of operating but also the amount of sludge [10,11]. Hence, the innovation of BAFs has attracted more attention. Chen et al. designed an
-BAF system to realize SPN. In this system, P removal and the denitrification occurred in
, while the nitrification occurred in BAF [5]. Zhang et al. applied a modified BAF system configured Fe-C micro electrolysis
Received 23 June 2022; Received in revised form 31 August 2022; Accepted 9 October 2022
Fig. 1. (a) Photographs of the ceramsite and quartz; (b) schematic diagram of the set-up for dynamic leaching and P removal; (c) schematic diagrams of BAFs for
-N and P removal (R1-ceramsite, R0-quartz and R0 respectively).

to enhance P and ciprofloxacin removal. They indicated that configuring Fe-C micro electrolysis significantly enhanced P removal, whereas had no promotion on N removal [12]. Dong et al. found that a BAF packed with porous ceramsites prepared from the high silicon iron tailings was effective for the treatment of organic wastewater, and the removal efficiency of chemical oxygen demand (COD),

-N (39.77 mg/L) and P (3.97 mg/L) were 91, 85 and 80 %, respectively [13]. Additionally, novel filter media, such as zeolite, granular activated carbon and various ceramsites, have been employed in BAFs to support biofilm and separate solid particles for wastewater treatment [14,15]. However, the previous studies mainly concentrate on the alteration of system operations to improve the removal efficiency of pollutants, the fundamental function of filter media is relatively single and their specific removal contribution is still unclear.

Currently, ceramsites prepared from various solid wastes have drawn wide attention because of their low investment cost and satisfactory performance, e.g., rough surface, high porosity and physicochemical stability [13,15-17]. These characteristics of filter media can promote the formation of multiple species of microorganisms to constitute biofilm [13,16]. Moreover, some specific ceramsites have been proved to have obvious advantages in adsorption, such as
from aqueous solutions in recent years [18,19]. Hence, the invention of a multifunctional ceramsite may be a viable approach to enhance the removal efficiency of
in BAFs. In our previous studies [20,21], a porous slow-release
ceramsite was discovered, using industrial solid wastes, i.e., lime mud and fly ash, as raw materials. This ceramsite has the ability to release
, so it is possible to realize P removal by forming hydroxyapatite
[22]. In addition, the nitrification is carried out by aerobic, autotrophic bacteria that oxidize
with molecular oxygen as an electron acceptor [23], as shown in Eqs. (1) and (2).
is the by-product of the nitrification and can suppress the constant transformation of

if there is no external alkalinity to neutralize it [24]. Wang et al. reported that the nitrification rate was sensitive to pH and could be sharply lowered if the pH changed from 7.0 to 5.8-6.0 [25]. Encouragingly,

released from the prepared ceramsite may be able to regulate the pH in BAFs for the nitrification spontaneously, without the addition of external alkalinity. As a consequence, it is promising and revolutionary to apply the porous slow-release
ceramsite as the filter medium in a single BAF to realize the simultaneous removal of
-N and P. Then, the complete SPN can be achieved by the assistance of a simple denitrification process [5,26].
In this study, the porous slow-release

ceramsite made from solid wastes was the primary focus. It was applied as an adsorbent to remove P from simulated wastewater using static and dynamic adsorption. Meanwhile, a novel BAF packed with the ceramsite was set up to monitor the efficiency of the simultaneous removal of
-N and P over a long-term operation for 231 days. The objectives of this study were (a) to determine the
slow-release and pH self-adjustment ability of the ceramsite; (b) to evaluate the effectiveness of the ceramsite in the simultaneous removal of

-N and P; (c) to explore the multifunctionality of the ceramsite in the novel BAF. The results will provide a new strategy for wastewater treatment and a theoretical basis for the filter media selection of BAFs in the future.
The ceramsite was prepared by using lime mud and fly ash with a

ceramsite. As industrial solid wastes, lime mud was obtained from Xinda Paper Industry Co. Ltd (Jiangsu, China) and fly ash was obtained from Huaneng Nanjing Power Station (Jiangsu, China). Chemical compositions of the raw materials and the detailed preparation process were described in the previous study [20].

Quartz, a kind of common calcium-free filter media, was purchased from Nanjing Dongji new building materials Co. Ltd (Jiangsu, China). It was used as a control material to evaluate the contribution of slow-release ability and porous structure of the ceramsite to
-N and P removal [26]. Physical properties of the ceramsite and quartz (Fig. 1(a)) are shown in Table S1. Three kinds of crystalline phases, i.e., anorthite
as raw materials and sintering at
to assist the analysis of the slow-release ability of the ceramsite. All reagents were of analytical grade and used as received. All solutions were prepared with deionized water.
A lab-scale cylindrical reactor was made of polymethyl methacrylate and its effective working volume was
. The reactor was separately filled with different filter media with a height of
to conduct continuously running experiments according to different requirements. The filter media were supported by a layer of pebbles (height of

was gradually reduced from the bottom to the top. A perforated pipe was set in the pebble layer to provide aeration by an air-blower (Model ACO-003, Sensen, China). The influent was continuously fed to the reactor through a peristaltic pump (Model BT100-2J, Longer, England), and the effluent overflowed from the top. The schematic diagrams were presented in Fig. 1(b)(c).
Static and dynamic leaching experiments were respectively conducted to investigate the release of

conical flask. The flasks were immersed in a water bath (Model SHA-A, Tianrui, China) of

The dynamic adsorption was operated continuously for 95 days in the reactor in Fig. 1(b).

-N and P was carried out by novel BAFs shown in Fig. 1(c). The BAF packed with quartz and without any filter medium were served as controls and referred as R0-quartz and R0, respectively. The simulated municipal wastewater with
-N was used in this part and its composition was as follows:
, respectively [27,28]. The detailed composition of trace element solution SL-4 was prepared according to Shen et al. [29]. Considering that the contribution of
and buffer solution (sodium acetate) were not included in the simulated wastewater. In addition, the concentration of
in the influent was gradually decreased by

every 3 days until it was completely cut out because municipal wastewater exhibits the characteristic of low organic carbon/nitrogen ratio [7]. The activated sludge with an initial mixed liquid volatile suspended solids (MLVSS) of
was obtained from a WWTP in Nantong economic development zone (Jiangsu, China).
Initially, the BAF reactor was sterilized and filled with

aeration, the simulated wastewater was continuously fed into the reactor in an up-flow manner. It is well known that the nitrification is a slow process. And referring to the studies of Huang et al. and Yu et al., the HRT was set to
in order to promote the evolution of nitrifiers into dominant bacteria and realize an efficient
-N removal [26,30]. The airflow rate was set to
and dissolved oxygen (DO) was controlled in the range of

[26]. A long-time running (231 days for R1-ceramsite, 109 days for R0-quartz and R0) was conducted for the BAFs. Backwashing and sludge discharge were not included in all operational BAFs and water samples were taken every day from the effluent.
Crystalline phase analysis of samples was performed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Model D8 Advance, BRUKER, Germany) with

. Pore size distribution and surface area of the ceramsite were identified by nitrogen adsorption using BET surface area analyzer (Model V-Sorb 2800P, Jinaipu, China) and concurrently measured by mercury porosimeter (Model GT-60, Quantachrome, America). The stereomicroscope (Model SZ6060, Yongxin, China) was applied to observe the morphology of the ceramsite. Furthermore, morphological features of filter media and sludge were detailed using scanning electron microscope (SEM, Model Gemini SEM 300, ZEISS, Germany). Particularly, the sludge was collected by centrifugation and washed by deionized water several times. When the three BAFs reached a steady status, the ceramsite, quartz and sludge were sampled to measure the microbial morphology. The samples were put into
. The fixed samples were washed by phosphate buffer solution
three times (10 min each), and then subjected to dehydration processes via gradient ethanol for
ethanol three times). The dehydrated samples were put into a solution of acetic acid and isoamyl acetate (1:1) for
and then isoamyl acetate only for another
. Following critical point drying, the samples were sprayed with gold and observed by the mentioned SEM.
Each sample collected in the above experiments at different time periods was immediately filtered through a

until chemical analysis was performed. And at least three independent analysis data were averaged for each sampling. The pH was measured by pH meter (Model PHS-3C, INESA, China). DO was monitored by dissolved oxygen meter (Model JPB-607A, INESA, China).

Microbial composition of the three BAFs was evaluated by sequencing of 16S rRNA gene. Total genomic DNA was extracted following the instruction of the E.Z.N.A. Soil DNA kit (Omega Bio-Tek, Inc., Norcross, GA, USA). The bacterial 16S rRNA gene V3-V4 was amplified using the primers 515F and 806R. Then these sequences were analyzed on a high-throughput Illumina MiSeq sequencing platform by Sangon Biotech Co. Ltd (Shanghai, China).

In order to determine the contribution of crystalline phases to the slow-release ability of the ceramsite, their XRD patterns were compared in Fig. 2 firstly. Corresponding to PDF 41-1486, PDF 35-0755 and PDF 74-0874, anorthite, gehlenite and wollastonite with no impurities were successfully synthesized using analytic reagents, which were labeled as A, G and W respectively in Fig. 2(a). These three crystalline phases were also observed in the ceramsite in Fig. 2(b). Considering that the ceramsite was prepared from industrial solid wastes, some alkali metal ions, such as
, and the small particle size in raw materials could effectively reduce the sintering temperature [31]. Hence, these
Fig. 4. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm (a) and pore size distribution (b) of the ceramsite.
three crystalline phases were generated simultaneously in the ceramsite after being sintered at
, which could be identified as a kind of Ca-rich material. Previous studies showed that Ca-rich materials can effectively remove P from wastewater by releasing
to react with phosphate [22]. Thus, the prepared ceramsite had the possibility to be regarded as an environmentally friendly and versatile material.

Porosity is an important structural parameter of filter media, including the morphology and dimension of the pores. The morphology of the ceramsite was observed by stereomicroscope and SEM respectively, and compared with quartz in Fig. 3. Surface of the ceramsite was rough enough in Fig. 3(a). Some visible macropores with diameters of approximately

were irregularly distributed, as shown in the cross-section image in Fig. 3(b). SEM image in Fig. 3(c) further confirmed the existence of interconnected macropores inside the ceramsite. They were caused by the release of gases (mainly
), which were generated by the decomposition of
in lime mud during the sintering process [20]. As shown in Table S1, the ceramsite had a low bulk density of

, which were also crucial physical properties associated with its porous structure. In comparison, the pore in quartz was relatively less and smaller in Fig. 3(d). The porous structure could provide enough channels and active sites for chemical and physical adsorption [32]. And in BAFs, the rough surface and porous structure were suitable for the attachment, growth and reproduction of microbial biofilm and the conduction of nutrition and oxygen [33].

To further understand the porous structure of the prepared ceram-site, nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm test was performed. The result shown in Fig. 4(a) was an atypical isotherm for non-porous or macroporous adsorbents, which broadly exhibited type II character with type H3 hysteresis loop. In addition, the adsorption capacity increased rapidly near

, elucidating that the pore adsorption had not reached saturation equilibrium yet and there might be numerous macropores in the ceramsite. However, according to the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC), this classification of the obtained adsorption isotherm was still somewhat tenuous for two reasons. First, considering that the isotherm was neither convex nor concave in relation to the
axis but rather a nominally straight line of fluctuating linearity, it was evident that the isotherm displayed neither typical behaviors of type II nor III. Second, the isotherm failed to completely
release curves of different materials (a) and pH values of the aqueous solutions (b) in static leaching experiments.

), i.e., existing low-pressure hysteresis [34]. Hereto, applying BET theory to analyze macropores in the ceramsite seemed to be inappropriate because its pore diameter was beyond the upper limit of determination by gas adsorption, nominally
Mercury intrusion measurement is usually used to analyze the larger pores with diameter of
, so the pore size distribution of the prepared ceramsite was obtained by this measurement and illustrated in Fig. 4(b). It could be seen that there were two critical peaks in the diameter range of
was dominant. Meanwhile, some structure parameters, such as specific intruded volume of

, were also measured. Combined with stereomicroscope and SEM images in Fig. 3, the ceramsite had a wide range of pore size distribution and was a macroporous material with large inner space and abundant combination points of adsorption. Generally, the size of bacteria is

or less, and the optimal microbial adhesion occurs when the size of pores is 1-5 times that of bacteria [22]. Therefore, microorganisms would be likely to achieve sustained growth of population in the interconnected macropores of the ceramsite, which in turn would be conducive to the efficiency of wastewater treatment.

The ceramsite used in this study was a comprehensive utilization of lime mud and fly ash by sintering method. As industrial solid wastes, these two raw materials contained various toxic and harmful substances, such as heavy metals [20]. The release of

might be conducive and positive in wastewater treatment, however, excessive leaching of heavy metals would definitely cause secondary pollution. Toxicity leaching test was conducted for the ceramsite and the results were displayed in Table S2. After being sintered at

, the leaching concentrations of heavy metals were much lower than the identification standards for extraction toxicity of the United States and China. Therefore, it was likely that heavy metals in raw materials were immobilized and the prepared ceramsite was a kind of environmentally friendly material.
Previous experiments related to this study demonstrated that

release efficiency was affected by the formulation and dosage of ceramsites, the initial pH and temperature of aqueous solutions [21]. Thereinto, the formulation essentially determined the composition of crystalline phases in the ceramsite. Hence, investigating the contribution of crystalline phases to
release was conducive to explaining the multifunctionality of the ceramsite in wastewater treatment. In static leaching experiments,
concentration of the ceramsite was compared with that of pure crystalline phases in Fig. 5(a). Obviously,
concentration of wollastonite was much higher than that of gehlenite and anorthite, and the maximum value of

respectively) with the increased leaching time. The discrepancy might be caused by the position of
in crystal structures, which determined the freedom degree of

release curve and pH values of the aqueous solution in dynamic leaching experiment with the ceramsite.

It had been demonstrated in Section 3.2 that the porous slow-release
ceramsite could remove P efficiently. However, it remained unknown whether the created alkaline environment was suitable for microbial growth and conducive to the simultaneous removal of

-N and P. Thus, quartz without slow-release ability and porous structure was introduced as a control (R0-quartz). In addition, a BAF with activated sludge only was designed as another control (R0). For the three BAFs, the concentrations of

-P in the effluent were monitored and then the removal efficiency with time was calculated and compared in Fig. 9. Notably, R1-ceramsite was far more effective compared with R0-quartz and R0, on account of the higher removal efficiency and longer operational time. As illustrated in Fig. 9(a), P removal efficiency of R1-ceramsite was stabilized
) in the first 180 days and then slightly decreased to
) until the 231th day. However, P removal of R0-quartz and R0 was similar and fluctuant. Their P removal efficiencies decreased sharply from
within 29 days. This striking contrast suggested that P removal in the BAFs depended deeply on the ceramsite. The better operating performance of R1-ceramsite could also be seen from
-N removal efficiency in Fig. 9 (b). In terms of R1-ceramsite,
in the beginning 9 days, and then sharply increased to
in the next 12 days, which might be related to the domestication and film-forming of microorganisms. After that,
). A slight decrease was observed from the 185th day and finally a removal efficiency of
-N (b) and pH (c) in the three BAFs.

, while that of R0 only fluctuated between
. These results indicated that the nitrification process was more stable and efficient with the regulation of the ceramsite in R1-ceramsite. In summary, concentrations of
-N in the effluent of R1-ceramsite had met Class I of the discharge standard for WWTPs (GB 18918-2002).
In order to observe the nitrification process in detail, the time cause of
-N and pH in the three BAFs was presented in Fig. 10. For R1-ceramsite and R0-quartz,
-N was significantly detected in the effluent throughout the experiment in Fig. 10(a). There was a sharp increase in their concentrations in the beginning 25 days, indicating
cultivating biofilm was successful and fast. Then, their concentrations were both kept around
, while the data fluctuation of R1-ceramsite was less than that of R0-quartz. In this stage, it could be calculated that
by the nitrification. Moreover, the durability of the high-efficiency stage of R1-ceramsite was much longer than that of R0-quartz. Finally, the decreased
concentration demonstrated that the nitrification process was suppressed and the environment in the reactors might be changed. In Fig. 10(b),
was just detected in R1-ceramsite in the beginning 49 days. Thus, it could be inferred that the nitrification was the main removal mechanism of
and the performance of R1-ceramsite was more stable and durable.
During the operational process, no additional pH buffer reagents were added to the three BAFs. According to Fig. 10(c), only the pH of R1-ceramsite was adjusted to alkaline
in the beginning. It was kept higher than that of R0-quartz and R0 within the comparable 80 days and then remained around 6.0 until the end. This indicated that the consumption of
was remedied persistently by the slow-release ability of the ceramsite to ensure the efficient nitrification.

To further explore the adaptability of microorganisms to the ceramsite, SEM images of the biofilm morphology in the three BAFs after 100 days operation were compared in Fig. 11. In terms of the ceramsite, Fig. 11(a-d) demonstrated that abundant fusiform diatoms along with slender and filamentous bacteria, Brevibacterium (rod-shaped) and Cocci (spherical-shaped) formed the biofilm structure. Zhang et al. illustrated that filamentous, rod, and spherical-shaped bacteria commonly existed in the aerobic biofilm during

removal [40]. However, the biofilm in R0-quartz and R0 had a lower bacteria density and did not contain diatoms in Fig. 11(e) and (f). Algae was a ubiquitous kind of phytoplankton and algal biofilms have been demonstrated to be an effective nutrient removal option for wastewater treatment [41]. Kesaano et al. reported that under Si-rich and N-deficient conditions, diatoms dominated the algae biofilm community [41].
contents in lime mud and fly ash were

, respectively, so the prepared ceramsite as a Si-rich material could provide diatoms with Si to build cell walls and frustules. Some researchers believed that the oxygen produced by algal photosynthesis was beneficial to nitrifiers in the biofilm, and the intensive nitrification would be stimulated correspondingly [42]. Moreover, algal photosynthesis could also elevate the pH [43]. With the contribution of both diatoms and the ceramsite, the pH of R1-ceramsite was controlled at

with no further decrease (Fig. 10(c)). Therefore, the stable biofilm morphology and enhanced removal performance of R1-ceramsite indicated that it was in a good and mature micro-ecological environment.
During the later period of the experiments in this part, there was an obvious decrease in

-N removal efficiency in Fig. 9(b), so microbial community structure analysis was undertaken using 16S rRNA sequencing for the three BAFs. Samples were collected from the bottom of the reactors 10 days before the end of the experiment. The top ten phyla with relative abundance of the microbial species were shown in Fig. 12. The predominant species in R1-ceramsite were Planctomycetes
with the remaining identified as Firmicutes
. However, the dominant species in R0-quartz and R0 were Proteobacteria (56.14 and

), respectively. Referring to the study of Almomani, Proteobacteria was among the most widely detected bacterial species in activated sludge, which was responsible for N removal through the nitrification and could aid in P removal in wastewater treatment [2]. Other bacteria associated with the nitrification identified in this study were Acidobacteria, Actinobacteria, Bacteroidetes and Firmicutes, which was consistent with the results reported by Zhang et al. [44]. Especially, Planctomycetes and Chloroflexi were also found, which could induce the occurrence of anaerobic N removal. For example,
Fig. 11. SEM images of the biofilm after 100 days operation: (a-d) R1-ceramsite; (e) R0-quartz; (f) R0.
Fig. 12. Comparison of the microbial communities in the three BAFs.

anaerobic ammonium oxidation could be conducted by Planctomycetes, as shown in Eq. (9) [45]. Considering that backwashing and sludge discharge processes were not designed for the BAFs in this study, the available pore space in the filter layer might decrease after a long operation. Then, oxygen mass transport was limited in the reactors and the uneven distribution of DO was developing [8]. As a result, nitrifiers were active in the areas with high DO concentration, whereas anaerobic bacteria were active in the anoxic areas [10]. Anyway, this situation was detrimental to the nitrification process and the long-term operation of the whole system, so backwashing and sludge discharge with appropriate frequency should be considered in the further research.
Due to the lack of organic matter and alternate anaerobic and aerobic

conditions, BAFs are generally incapable of biological P removal [46]. In the above analysis of biofilms (Part 3.3.2), bacteria associated with P removal were not identified indeed. Hence, the contribution of biological P removal could be ignored and the outstanding P removal in this study should be attributed to chemical and physical adsorption. Given the presence of
in the influent here, the formation of struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate,

also became possible [47]. However, the low and unstable P removal efficiency of R0-quartz and R0 indicated that these two precipitates could only bring limited P removal when the pH could not be regulated spontaneously. Thus, owing to the slow-release ability and porous structure of the ceramsite, the formation and adsorption of

ensured the highly efficient P removal in R1-ceramsite. In addition, Wang et al. reported that the extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) could increase the adhesivity of precipitates due to its adhesive nature and hence facilitate precipitates aggregation, so the

migration of precipitates in the filter layer would be limited [25]. Although the height of the filter layer and concentration of suspended solids (SS) had no obvious increase, the more precipitates generated, the faster depletion of the available pore space in the filter layer was and the lower removal efficiencies of
-N and P were. Therefore, backwashing and sludge discharge with appropriate frequency could be designed to optimize the BAF in the further research.
The contributions of slow-release ability and porous structure of the ceramsite to
-N and P removal were investigated in this study. The obtained results indicated that wollastonite and porous structure played an important role in

slow-release process of the ceramsite. In the static and dynamic adsorption experiments, P was removed by forming hydroxyapatite and then adsorbing into the ceramsite. In the BAF, the created alkaline environment was beneficial to the growth of nitrifiers, which ensured the efficient nitrification to remove

-N. In addition, the intensive nitrification was stimulated by diatoms photosynthesis. P removal in the BAF was also a result of chemical and physical adsorption. Therefore, the prepared ceramsite could be regarded as an environmentally friendly and versatile material to deal with both solid wastes and wastewater.
